Award.AbstractNarration:
In order to create a more highly qualified and diverse technology workforce in information assurance to better serve the security needs of business and industry, this project at Moreno Valley College (MVC) in southern California is designed to develop a new Information Systems Auditing (ISA) associate degree and certificate program. To improve training and increase the number of certified ISA technicians while advancing the role of community colleges in Career and Technical Education (CTE), the college will address emerging ISA needs of industries and organizations. The core ISA certificate program is designed to serve low-income, first generation, and traditionally underrepresented student populations and meet their educational, economic, and career needs, which will model the culture of collaboration and partnership established between the college and regional business and industry, government and workforce organizations, K-12 districts, the community, and four-year universities. Focusing on the expertise of leaders in the field and these partnerships, the project will develop networks to support current and future technical workforce needs, internships, and other aspects of implementation. It will encourage participation by low-income, underrepresented, and/or minority students including women, with a target goal to increase and improve computer information systems (CIS) education not only at the college, but nationwide. The outcome of the efforts will affect students and instructors from high schools to colleges and universities and will positively impact the growing industries relocating to the region by improving the quality, quantity, and diversity in the workforce available to them, while making small to medium businesses more secure through regular security assessments. Project findings will be widely disseminated as it is designed to build an improved model of internship/work experiences that can be replicable at community colleges and universities nationwide and can be modified in order to meet the needs of individual institutions. A rigorous evaluation process will be employed to enhance the project activities and provide opportunities for researching and determining the success of the project and deliverables.

The project includes student internships and work experiences; experiential learning; the application of knowledge for students; and systems security audits for local and regional businesses and industry. Students will gain soft and technical skills necessary to become highly-skilled ISA technicians in a business environment. The project provides an opportunity for students, primarily first generation or underrepresented, to gain a rigorous education in ISA and participate in relevant information systems opportunities and work experience through internships. The project will also provide faculty members with professional development opportunities to enhance researched pedagogy and teaching strategies in technology disciplines. It will create a blueprint for project improvement that incorporates a new model of success by developing or modifying core and transferrable CIS courses. Building on the foundation of regional workforce needs, the project will improve the training and quality of ISA technicians in the service areas of the college. With student success and employment preparation at the core of the planning and development, the second step will be the development of an Associate of Science (A.S.) transfer degree program in Information Systems (IS) to follow the certificate program.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Moreno Valley College (MVC) contributes to the scientific and technological fields of study with its new Information Systems Auditing (ISA) certificate program through NSF?s Advanced Technological Education (ATE) project, ?Leading Today?s Student into Tomorrow?s Technology (LTSTT)?. The project includes student internship/work experience opportunities; experiential learning; the application of knowledge for students; and systems security audits for local and regional businesses and industry. Students engaged in the project gain the soft and technical skills necessary to become highly-skilled ISA technicians in a business environment. To improve training and increase the number of certified ISA technicians while advancing the role of community colleges in Career and Technical Education, MVC addresses emerging ISA needs of industries and organizations. Establishing a core ISA certificate program designed to serve low-income, first generation, and traditionally underrepresented student populations and meet educational, economic, and career needs is central to the project. LTSTT models the culture of collaboration and partnership established between MVC and regional businesses while building an improved model of internship/work experiences easily replicated for other colleges and universities. MVC partners with regional business and industry, government and workforce organizations, K-12 school districts, the community, and 4-year universities.

LTSTT provides an opportunity for MVC students, most of whom are first generation or underrepresented, to gain a rigorous education in ISA, participate in relevant information systems opportunities, and work experience through internships. LTSTT also provides faculty with professional development opportunities to enhance researched pedagogy and teaching strategies in technology disciplines. MVC creates a blueprint for project improvement that incorporates a new model of success by developing or modifying core and transferrable Computer Information Systems (CIS) courses.

The project encompasses activities advancing scientific knowledge, discovery, and engagement, providing broader impact through partnerships with middle schools and high schools, industry and small businesses, through educating more diverse Technology workforce. LTSTT, which has developed and implemented an ISA certificate on at MVC, encourages participation by populations traditionally underrepresented in STEM education and careers including students from low-income backgrounds, minority students, and women.  The project?s primary focus is to increase and improve CIS education locally, regionally, and nationally. Building on the foundation of regional workforce needs, MVC is improving the training and quality of ISA technicians in our immediate service areas. Focusing on the expertise and partnerships developed with industry and leading experts, LTSTT has developed networks supporting current and future technical workforce needs and internships by creating an educational pipeline for future technicians, beginning with partnerships with local middle schools and high schools to increase early engagement, educational opportunities, and career interest.  Through the LTSST project, MVC now offers dual enrollment opportunities for high school students in ISA courses, where students earn high school and college credit in foundational CIS courses in the certificate program.  Local and regional interest among both middle school and high school students is fostered through partnerships in cybersecurity-related extracurricular partnerships including local and regional CyberPatriot competitions, and Cybersecurity and Coding Summer Camps. MVC continues to disseminate project findings based on best practices, allowing for easy replication and customization of the project at any academic institution. With student success and employment preparation at the core of the project?s planning and development, MVC is advancing computer science and cybersecurity education by developing an Associate of Science (A.S.) transfer degree program in Information Systems. The outcome of MVC?s efforts will continue to advance computer science education across the continuum of education to career pipelines, and positively impacts the growing industries relocating to our region.   MVC is ensuring greater cybersecurity by improving the quality, quantity, and diversity in the technical workforce available to business and industry throughout the region.
